summary.en:
The first chapter of the Bhagavad Gita - Arjuna Vishada Yoga introduces the setup, the setting, the characters and the circumstances that led to the epic battle of Mahabharata, fought between the Pandavas and the Kauravas. It outlines the reasons that led to the revelation of the of Bhagavad Gita.
As both armies stand ready for the battle, the mighty warrior Arjuna, on observing the warriors on both sides becomes increasingly sad and depressed due to the fear of losing his relatives and friends and the consequent sins attributed to killing his own relatives. So, he surrenders to Lord Krishna, seeking a solution. Thus, follows the wisdom of the Bhagavad Gita.

slocks.shlok_name:
धृतराष्ट्र उवाच ।

धर्मक्षेत्रे कुरुक्षेत्रे समवेता युयुत्सवः ।
मामकाः पाण्डवाश्चैव किमकुर्वत सञ्जय ॥ १-१॥
slocks.meaning: Dhṛutarāṣhṭra said: O Sañjaya, after my sons and the sons of Pāṇḍu assembled in the place of pilgrimage at Kurukṣhetra, desiring to fight, what did they do?
slocks.summary:
King Dhritarashtra was blind from birth and also devoid of spiritual knowledge. Due to his infatuation with his sons, he deviated from the path of truth and usurped the rightful right of kingship of the Pandavas. Regarding the injustice he had done to his own nephews, the sons of Pandu. He was fully conscious. It was because of this guilt that he was worried about the outcome of the war and that is why he was questioning Sanjay about the battle being fought on the desert of Kurukshetra.

In this verse, Dhritarashtra asks Sanjay the question that his and Pandu's sons gathered in the battlefield. What did the latter do? Now it was quite clear that they had gathered for the sole purpose of making war. So naturally they would make war. What was the need for Dhritarashtra to question what they had done.

He knew his apprehension. The words he used—'dharma kshetre', meaning that which is holy land—come from it. Kurukshetra was a holy land. It is described in the Shatapatha Brahmana as Kurukshetram Deva Yajnam. Kurukshetra is the abode of the gods of heaven.As such, this is the land where religion is nurtured. Dhritarashtra feared that as a result of the influence of the holy land of Kurukshetra, some of his sons might not develop the sense of discernment between right and wrong, and they would begin to realize that it was wrong to kill their kinsmen, the Pandavas. Thinking so, they might even agree to a peaceful settlement. Such prospects caused deep despair in Dhritarashtra's mind. He began to think that if his sons accepted the proposal of a truce, the Pandavas would constantly put obstacles in his way, and so In his view, war was inevitable. Also, he was uncertain about the outcome of the war and wanted to be sure about the fate of his sons. Consequently, he asked Sanjay about the goings-on on the battlefield of Kurukshetra, where the two armies had assembled.

slocks.shlok_name:
सञ्जय उवाच ।

दृष्ट्वा तु पाण्डवानीकं व्यूढं दुर्योधनस्तदा ।
आचार्यमुपसङ्गम्य राजा वचनमब्रवीत् ॥ १-२॥
slocks.meaning: Sañjaya said: O King, after looking over the army arranged in military formation by the sons of Pāṇḍu, King Duryodhana went to his teacher and spoke the following words.
slocks.summary:
Dhritarashtra wanted to make sure that his sons were still ready to fight. Sanjay understood the meaning of Dhritarashtra's question and assured him that the Pandavas were strategizing and ready for war. Changing the subject of the conversation later he said or what Duryodhana was doing.

Dhritarashtra's eldest son Duryodhana had a very evil and cruel nature. Dhritarashtra was blind from birth and practically ruled the kingdom of Hastinapur. was determined, so that he could rule unopposed. His assumption was that the Pandavas would never be able to gather a large enough army to face his army. But contrary to his assumption, Duryodhana was dismayed and disheartened to see the large army of the Pandavas. Duryodhana's approach to his guru shows that he was apprehensive about the outcome of the war. He went to him pretending to show respect to Dronacharya but in reality he wanted to hide his anxiety. So he spoke the nine stanzas beginning now.

slocks.shlok_name:
पश्यैतां पाण्डुपुत्राणामाचार्य महतीं चमूम् ।
व्यूढां द्रुपदपुत्रेण तव शिष्येण धीमता ॥ १-३॥
slocks.meaning: O my teacher, behold the great army of the sons of Pāṇḍu, so expertly arranged by your intelligent disciple the son of Drupada.
slocks.summary:
Duryodhana, being a skilled politician, wanted to point fingers at the past mistakes of his general, Guru Dronacharya. Dronacharya once had a political dispute with King Drupada. Enraged by this dispute, Drupada performed a yajna in revenge and received a boon. that he would get a son, who would be able to kill Dronacharya. As a result of this boon, he had a son named Dhrishtadyumna.

Although Dronacharya knew the purpose of Dhrishtadyumna's birth, when Drupada entrusted his son Dhrishtadyumna to Dronacharya to teach him the art of war, he was generous. Hriday Dronacharya spared no qualms in mastering Dhrishtadyumna in the art of war. Now Dhrishtadyumna was on the side of the Pandavas as the captain of their army, who prepared the strategy of the entire army. Thus Duryodhana wanted to signal to his guru that due to his generosity in the past, he should face the present crisis. is falling and should no longer show any leniency in fighting the Pandavas.

slocks.shlok_name:
अत्र शूरा महेष्वासा भीमार्जुनसमा युधि ।
युयुधानो विराटश्च द्रुपदश्च महारथः ॥ १-४॥
slocks.meaning: Here in this army are many heroic bowmen equal in fighting to Bhīma and Arjuna: great fighters like Yuyudhāna, Virāṭa and Drupada.
slocks.summary: Seeing the impending danger before him, Duryodhana begins to believe that the army gathered by the Pandavas is much larger than it really is.

slocks.shlok_name:
धृष्टकेतुश्चेकितानः काशिराजश्च वीर्यवान् ।
पुरुजित्कुन्तिभोजश्च शैब्यश्च नरपुङ्गवः ॥ १-५॥
slocks.meaning: There are also great, heroic, powerful fighters like Dhṛuṣhṭaketu, Chekitāna, Kāshirāja, Purujit, Kuntibhoja and Shaibya.
slocks.summary: To express his concern, Duryodhana pointed out that Maharathis (great warriors, who alone have the strength of ten thousand ordinary warriors) from the Pandava army were present to fight.

slocks.shlok_name:
युधामन्युश्च विक्रान्त उत्तमौजाश्च वीर्यवान् ।
सौभद्रो द्रौपदेयाश्च सर्व एव महारथाः ॥ १-६॥
slocks.meaning: There are the mighty Yudhāmanyu, the very powerful Uttamaujā, the son of Subhadrā and the sons of Draupadī. All these warriors are great chariot fighters.
slocks.summary: Duryodhana referred to the exceptionally mighty warriors of the Pandava army who were mighty great commanders like Arjuna and Bhima, who would be difficult to defeat in battle.

slocks.shlok_name:
अस्माकं तु विशिष्टा ये तान्निबोध द्विजोत्तम ।
नायका मम सैन्यस्य संज्ञार्थं तान्ब्रवीमि ते ॥ १-७॥
slocks.meaning: But for your information, O best of the brāhmaṇas, let me tell you about the captains who are especially qualified to lead my military force.
slocks.summary:
Here the Pradhan of the Kaurava army addresses Dronacharya as Duryodhana Dvijottam (the best of the twice-born or the best of the brahmins). He deliberately uses this word to address his guru. Actually Dronacharya was not a warrior by profession, he was only a warrior. Acharya. Like a treacherous hero, Duryodhana was raising shameless doubts about his own Guru's loyalty. The hidden meaning of Duryodhana's words was that if Dronacharya did not fight bravely, he would be considered a Brahmin, whose interest was in treating and serving the food served in Duryodhana's kingdom. The coming comforts will have to be enjoyed.

Saying this, Duryodhana now wanted to strengthen the morale of himself and his Guru and therefore he started enumerating the great generals of his army.

slocks.shlok_name:
भवान्भीष्मश्च कर्णश्च कृपश्च समितिञ्जयः ।
अश्वत्थामा विकर्णश्च सौमदत्तिस्तथैव च ॥ १-८॥
slocks.meaning: There are personalities like you, Bhīṣhma, Karṇa, Kṛupa, Ashvatthāmā, Vikarṇa and the son of Somadatta called Bhūrishravā, who are always victorious in battle.

slocks.shlok_name:
अन्ये च बहवः शूरा मदर्थे त्यक्तजीविताः ।
नानाशस्त्रप्रहरणाः सर्वे युद्धविशारदाः ॥ १-९॥
slocks.meaning: There are many other heroes who are prepared to lay down their lives for my sake. All of them are well equipped with different kinds of weapons, and all are experienced in military science.

slocks.shlok_name:
अपर्याप्तं तदस्माकं बलं भीष्माभिरक्षितम् ।
पर्याप्तं त्विदमेतेषां बलं भीमाभिरक्षितम् ॥ १-१०॥
slocks.meaning: Our strength is immeasurable, and we are perfectly protected by Grandfather Bhīṣhma, whereas the strength of the Pāṇḍavas, carefully protected by Bhīma, is limited.
slocks.summary:
These self-praiseful words of Duryodhana were characteristically like the utterances of the vainglorious. When their end seems near, instead of humbly assessing the situation, self-praises become arrogant and wallow in vain self-praise. The poignant irony of his own future is reflected in Duryodhana's speech. , when he said that his power protected by Bhishma was limitless.

Bhishma Patamaha was the chief commander of the Kaurava army. He had the boon of timing his own death, which actually made him invincible. On the Pandava side, his army was protected by Bhima. was Duryodhana's natural enemy. Thus, Duryodhana compared Bhishma's strength to that of Bhishma. However, Bhishma was the grandfather of both the Kauravas and the Pandavas and actually wanted the welfare of both sides. His compassion for the Pandavas could have prevented him from making war too coldly. He also knew that in this holy war, where Sri Krishna himself is present, no power on earth could give victory to the side of adharma. And so, to fulfill his moral responsibility to Hastinapur and the Kauravas, he chose to wage war against the Pandavas. This decision underlines the subtle character of Bhishma Pitamaha's personality.

slocks.shlok_name:
अयनेषु च सर्वेषु यथाभागमवस्थिताः ।
भीष्ममेवाभिरक्षन्तु भवन्तः सर्व एव हि ॥ १-११॥
slocks.meaning: All of you must now give full support to Grandfather Bhīṣhma, as you stand at your respective strategic points of entrance into the phalanx of the army.
slocks.summary: Duryodhana felt that Bhishma would prove to be a formidable force in providing inspiration and passion to his army. Hence, he asked the generals of his army to stand firm in their respective positions and simultaneously protect Bhishma from all sides.

slocks.shlok_name:
तस्य सञ्जनयन्हर्षं कुरुवृद्धः पितामहः ।
सिंहनादं विनद्योच्चैः शङ्खं दध्मौ प्रतापवान् ॥ १-१२॥
slocks.meaning: Then Bhīṣhma, the great valiant grandsire of the Kuru dynasty, the grandfather of the fighters, blew his conchshell very loudly, making a sound like the roar of a lion, giving Duryodhana joy.
slocks.summary: Grandfather Bhishma sensed the fear in the heart of his great-grandson Duryodhana and in an attempt to placate him out of natural compassion for him, he chanted in a very loud voice. However, he knew that on the other side was the Supreme Lord Krishna Himself in the Pandava army. Being present, Duryodhana had no chance of winning the battle, yet wanted to convey to his great-grandson that he would fulfill his duty to fight, and would not show any laxity in this regard. was being initialized.

slocks.shlok_name:
ततः शङ्खाश्च भेर्यश्च पणवानकगोमुखाः ।
सहसैवाभ्यहन्यन्त स शब्दस्तुमुलोऽभवत् ॥ १-१३॥
slocks.meaning: After that, the conchshells, drums, bugles, trumpets and horns were all suddenly sounded, and the combined sound was tumultuous.
slocks.summary: Seeing Bhishma Pitamaha's intense eagerness for war, the Kauravasenas also became eager and started making a terrible noise with the instruments. Panava means drum, anak means mridanga, and gomukh means shrung. All these are musical instruments and they all combine The sound made a terrible noise.

slocks.shlok_name:
ततः श्वेतैर्हयैर्युक्ते महति स्यन्दने स्थितौ ।
माधवः पाण्डवश्चैव दिव्यौ शङ्खौ प्रदध्मतुः ॥ १-१४॥
slocks.meaning: On the other side, both Lord Kṛuṣhṇa and Arjuna, stationed on a great chariot drawn by white horses, sounded their transcendental conchshells.
slocks.summary:
After the sound of the conch-blowing of the Kaurava army had subsided, Lord Krishna and Arjuna, seated on a magnificent chariot, boldly blew the powerful conch-bones, igniting the Pandavas' eagerness for war.

Sanjaya uses the word 'Madhava' for Lord Krishna. 'Ma' Meaning goddess of fortune and 'dhav' means husband. Sri Krishna is the husband of goddess Lakshmi in the form of her Lord Vishnu. This verse shows that the goddess of fortune's mercy was on the side of the Pandavas, and they won a quick battle and regained their usurped throne. will attain.

Pandava means the sons of Pandava. Any of the five brothers is addressed as Pandava. Here, the term is used for Arjuna. The magnificent chariot on which he rode was gifted to him by Agnidev. was.

slocks.shlok_name:
पाञ्चजन्यं हृषीकेशो देवदत्तं धनञ्जयः ।
पौण्ड्रं दध्मौ महाशङ्खं भीमकर्मा वृकोदरः ॥ १-१५॥
slocks.meaning: Lord Kṛuṣhṇa blew His conchshell, called Pāñchajanya; Arjuna blew his, the Devadatta; and Bhīma, the voracious eater and performer of herculean tasks, blew his terrific conchshell, called Pauṇḍra.
slocks.summary: In this sloka the word Hrishikesh is used for Sri Krishna, which means Lord of mind and senses. Sri Krishna is the Lord of every living being and of His own mind and senses. Even while doing wonderful things on earth, He is the Lord of His own mind and senses. retained full ownership over.

slocks.shlok_name:
अनन्तविजयं राजा कुन्तीपुत्रो युधिष्ठिरः ।
नकुलः सहदेवश्च सुघोषमणिपुष्पकौ ॥ १-१६॥
slocks.meaning: O king, Yudhishthira blew his conch named Anantavijaya;
slocks.summary: Yudhisthira was the eldest of the Pandava brothers. Here he is referred to as 'king'; he earned the right to this title by performing the Rajasuya yajna and receiving praise from other kings.

slocks.shlok_name:
काश्यश्च परमेष्वासः शिखण्डी च महारथः ।
धृष्टद्युम्नो विराटश्च सात्यकिश्चापराजितः ॥ १-१७॥
slocks.meaning: When Nakul and Sahadeva blew the conch shells named Sughosh and Manipuspak.
slocks.summary: He possessed such regal dignity and magnanimity that, whether in the palace or exiled in exile, it always shone forth.

slocks.shlok_name:
द्रुपदो द्रौपदेयाश्च सर्वशः पृथिवीपते ।
सौभद्रश्च महाबाहुः शङ्खान्दध्मुः पृथक्पृथक् ॥ १-१८॥
slocks.meaning: King Yudhiṣhṭhira, the son of Kuntī, blew his conchshell, the Ananta-vijaya, and Nakula and Sahadeva blew the Sughoṣha and Maṇipuṣhpaka. That great archer the King of Kāshī, the great fighter Shikhaṇḍī, Dhṛuṣhṭadyumna, Virāṭa, the unconquerable Sātyaki, Drupada, the sons of Draupadī, and the others, O King, such as the mighty-armed son of Subhadrā, all blew their respective conchshells.
slocks.summary:
Drupado Draupadeyashcha sarvashah prthivipete .
Saubhadrascha mahabahu: shakhandadhamu: prithak prithak ॥ 18॥

slocks.shlok_name:
स घोषो धार्तराष्ट्राणां हृदयानि व्यदारयत् ।
नभश्च पृथिवीं चैव तुमुलोऽभ्यनुनादयन् ॥ १-१९॥
slocks.meaning: The blowing of these different conchshells became uproarious. Vibrating both in the sky and on the earth, it shattered the hearts of the sons of Dhṛutarāṣhṭra.
slocks.summary: The hearts of the soldiers of the Kaurava army were pierced by the sound of various conch shells blown by the Pandava army. However, the blowing of their conch shells by the Kaurava army did not have any adverse effect on the Pandava army. As the Pandavas took shelter of Sri Krishna , they had full confidence that they would be protected. The Kauravas, on the other hand, having resorted to their own force, and their consciences haunted by the guilt of their crimes, were terrified by the fear of defeat.

slocks.shlok_name:
अथ व्यवस्थितान्दृष्ट्वा धार्तराष्ट्रान् कपिध्वजः ।
प्रवृत्ते शस्त्रसम्पाते धनुरुद्यम्य पाण्डवः ॥ १-२०॥
हृषीकेशं तदा वाक्यमिदमाह महीपते ।
slocks.meaning: At that time Arjuna, the son of Pāṇḍu, seated in the chariot bearing the flag marked with Hanumān, took up his bow and prepared to shoot his arrows. O King, after looking at the sons of Dhṛutarāṣhṭra drawn in military array, Arjuna then spoke to Lord Kṛuṣhṇa these words.
slocks.summary: In this verse Arjuna is addressed to Kapidhwaja because of the presence of Mahavira Hanuman on his chariot. There is a story woven in the background. Once Arjuna was proud of his archery and told Sri Krishna that at the time of Sri Rama, the monkeys came from India. Why so much effort to build a bridge across the ocean to Lanka? If he had been there, he would have built the bridge with arrows. Shri Krishna asked him to demonstrate. Arjuna built the bridge with arrows. Shri Krishna called Hanuman and asked him to test the bridge. When The bridge began to break as the hero Hanuman began to walk on it. Arjuna realized that the bridge built by his arrows was never capable of carrying the weight of Lord Sri Rama's vast army, and he apologized for his mistake. One should not boast of skill. He generously gave Arjuna the boon that he would sit on his chariot throughout the Mahabharata war. Hence, Arjuna's chariot had a flag bearing the symbol of Hanumanji, hence its name 'Kapidhwaja' or 'Vanardhwaja'

slocks.shlok_name:
अर्जुन उवाच ।

सेनयोरुभयोर्मध्ये रथं स्थापय मेऽच्युत ॥ १-२१॥
slocks.meaning: Arjuna said, O Achyuta! Please make my chariot stand between the two armies
slocks.summary: Arjuna was an ardent devotee of Lord Krishna, who is the supreme lord of the entire creation. Yet, in this verse, Arjuna directs the Lord to take the chariot to the desired place as per his wish. This conveys the sweet relationship of the Lord with his devotees. Owing to naive love, God Himself becomes His servant

slocks.shlok_name:
यावदेतान्निरीक्षेऽहं योद्धुकामानवस्थितान् ।
कैर्मया सह योद्धव्यमस्मिन् रणसमुद्यमे ॥ १-२२॥
slocks.meaning:
Arjuna said:
O infallible one, please draw my chariot between the two armies so that I may see those present here, who desire to fight, and with whom I must contend in this great trial of arms.
slocks.summary:
Ah Bhaktaparadhi no hyasvatantra eva dvija

Sadhubhirabishitahdayo bhaktairbhaktajanapriya: (Bhagavatam 9.4.63)

Although I am supremely independent, I still become the servant of my devotees. They are very dear to me and their Out of love I owe him.” Gratified by Arjuna's devotion, Sri Krishna assumed the position of the charioteer, while Arjuna comfortably seated himself on the passenger's seat, giving him instructions.

slocks.shlok_name:
योत्स्यमानानवेक्षेऽहं य एतेऽत्र समागताः ।
धार्तराष्ट्रस्य दुर्बुद्धेर्युद्धे प्रियचिकीर्षवः ॥ १-२३॥
slocks.meaning: Let me see those who have come here to fight, wishing to please the evil-minded son of Dhṛutarāṣhṭra.
slocks.summary: The evil minded sons of Dhritarashtra had usurped the kingdom and hence the warriors fighting on their side were naturally evil in nature. Arjuna wanted to see the people with whom he had to fight in this war. At first Arjuna was eager to fight heroically. . So by calling Dhritarashtra's sons evil-minded, he wanted to convey how Duryodha had often plotted for the destruction of the Pandavas. Arjuna's attitude was, We were morally the officers of half the kingdom, but he wanted to usurp it. He is evil-minded and here he Even the kings gathered to help are evil. I want to observe those warriors, who are so anxious for war. They have favored injustice and therefore their destruction by us is certain.

slocks.shlok_name:
सञ्जय उवाच ।

एवमुक्तो हृषीकेशो गुडाकेशेन भारत ।
सेनयोरुभयोर्मध्ये स्थापयित्वा रथोत्तमम् ॥ १-२४॥
slocks.meaning:
Sañjaya said:
 O descendant of Bharata, having thus been addressed by Arjuna, Lord Kṛuṣhṇa drew up the fine chariot in the midst of the armies of both parties.

slocks.shlok_name:
भीष्मद्रोणप्रमुखतः सर्वेषां च महीक्षिताम् ।
उवाच पार्थ पश्यैतान्समवेतान्कुरूनिति ॥ १-२५॥
slocks.meaning: In the presence of Bhīṣhma, Droṇa and all the other chieftains of the world, the Lord said, Just behold, Pārtha, all the Kurus assembled here.
slocks.summary: The word Kuru is used for both the Kauravas and the Pandavas, as they are both descendants of the Kurus. Krishna purposely uses this word to awaken a sense of brotherhood in Arjuna and convince him that they are all one. .They wanted the brotherhood to create infatuation, which would distract Arjuna and as a result give Sri Krishna an opportunity to preach the divine doctrine of the Gita for the welfare of mankind in the future Kali Yuga. Hence, he replaced 'Dhartashtran' (sons of Dhritarashtra). used the word 'Kurun' (descendant of Kuru). Just as a physician first gives medicine to a patient suffering from boils to ease the pain and then performs surgery to remove the diseased part, the Lord, in exactly the same way, the illusory hidden in Arjuna. Mohan awakened first so that the latter could destroy it.

slocks.shlok_name:
तत्रापश्यत्स्थितान्पार्थः पितॄनथ पितामहान् ।
आचार्यान्मातुलान्भ्रातॄन्पुत्रान्पौत्रान्सखींस्तथा ॥ १-२६॥
श्वशुरान्सुहृदश्चैव सेनयोरुभयोरपि ।
slocks.meaning: There Arjuna could see, within the midst of the armies of both parties, his fathers, grandfathers, teachers, maternal uncles, brothers, sons, grandsons, friends, and also his fathers-in-law and well-wishers.

slocks.shlok_name:
तान्समीक्ष्य स कौन्तेयः सर्वान्बन्धूनवस्थितान् ॥ १-२७॥
कृपया परयाविष्टो विषीदन्निदमब्रवीत् ।
slocks.meaning: When the son of Kuntī, Arjuna, saw all these different grades of friends and relatives, he became overwhelmed with compassion and spoke thus.
slocks.summary: The sight of his kinsmen present on the battlefield drew Arjuna's attention for the first time to the consequences of this terrible war of fratricide. The mighty warrior who had appeared to fight and mentally put his enemies to death in revenge for the unjust treatment done to the Pandavas. He was ready, there was a sudden change of heart in Arjuna. Seeing his Kurus Bandhu gathered in enemy ranks, Arjuna's heart sank into grief, his intellect became deluded, his boldness in duty turned to cowardice, the firmness of his heart was replaced by tenderness. So , Sanjay addresses him as Kuntiputra (Mother's son) referring to the friendliness and generosity of his nature.

slocks.shlok_name:
अर्जुन उवाच ।

दृष्ट्वेमं स्वजनं कृष्ण युयुत्सुं समुपस्थितम् ॥ १-२८॥
सीदन्ति मम गात्राणि मुखं च परिशुष्यति ।
slocks.meaning:
Arjuna said:
 My dear Kṛuṣhṇa, seeing my friends and relatives present before me in such a fighting spirit, I feel the limbs of my body quivering and my mouth drying up
slocks.summary: Anurag can be either mundane or spiritual. Enchantment for one's relatives is a worldly affection, arising out of carnal conceptions of life. Believing ourselves to be a body, we become attached to the relatives of the body. This attachment is ignorance. is based on and drags one down to the mayic consciousness. Ultimately such attachment results in suffering, because, with the end of the body, family ties also come to an end. On the other hand, the Supreme Father God is our soul's father, mother, friend, guru, and Beloved. Accordingly, attachment to Him at the level of the soul is a spiritual attitude, which elevates the consciousness and illuminates the intellect. Love for God is like an ocean, in whose vastness all is absorbed, whereas love for carnal relations is narrow and discriminating. . Here, Arjuna was experiencing worldly attachment, which was drowning his mind in an ocean of depression, causing him to tremble at the mere thought of his duty.

slocks.shlok_name:
वेपथुश्च शरीरे मे रोमहर्षश्च जायते ॥ १-२९॥
गाण्डीवं स्रंसते हस्तात्त्वक्चैव परिदह्यते ।
slocks.meaning: My whole body is trembling, my hair is standing on end, my bow Gāṇḍīva is slipping from my hand, and my skin is burning.
slocks.summary: When Arjuna thought about the outcome of the war, he became worried and sad. The same Gandiva, whose mighty thunder used to make the enemies afraid,

slocks.shlok_name:
न च शक्नोम्यवस्थातुं भ्रमतीव च मे मनः ॥ १-३०॥
निमित्तानि च पश्यामि विपरीतानि केशव ।
slocks.meaning: I am now unable to stand here any longer. I am forgetting myself, and my mind is reeling. I see only causes of misfortune, O Kṛuṣhṇa, killer of the Keshī demon.
slocks.summary: was beginning to slip out of his hands. Fighting is a sin,

slocks.shlok_name:
न च श्रेयोऽनुपश्यामि हत्वा स्वजनमाहवे ॥ १-३१॥
न काङ्क्षे विजयं कृष्ण न च राज्यं सुखानि च ।
slocks.meaning: I do not see how any good can come from killing my own kinsmen in this battle, nor can I, my dear Kṛuṣhṇa, desire any subsequent victory, kingdom, or happiness.
slocks.summary: His mind began to become dizzy at the thought. Due to this unsteadiness of mind, he became possessed by inferior spirits and began to accept misleading ominous signs and foresaw disastrous and imminent consequences.

slocks.shlok_name: किं नो राज्येन गोविन्द किं भोगैर्जीवितेन वा ॥ १-३२॥
slocks.meaning: O Shri Krishna! I do not even desire victory, kingdom or happiness thus acquired.
slocks.summary: Arjuna's confusion stems from the fact that killing is a criminal act in itself, even killing one's relatives is an even more brutal act. Arjuna felt that even if he did such a cruel thing to gain the kingdom, the victory would bring him no happiness in the end. would not. He would be unable to share such fame with his friends and relatives, whom he would have to kill to achieve victory.

slocks.shlok_name:
येषामर्थे काङ्क्षितं नो राज्यं भोगाः सुखानि च ।
त इमेऽवस्थिता युद्धे प्राणांस्त्यक्त्वा धनानि च ॥ १-३३॥
slocks.meaning: What is the benefit of the kingdom, the pleasures or the life for which we long, they are all arrayed before us for battle.
slocks.summary: Here, Arjuna is exhibiting a low level of sensitivity, and is confused by idealism. Indifference to worldly possessions and material pleasures is an admirable spiritual virtue, but Arjuna is not feeling spiritual. On the contrary, his Illusion masquerading as words of compassion. Virtuous attitudes bring inner harmony, contentment, and happiness to the soul. If Arjuna's compassion were transcendental, he would have been elevated by such feelings, but his experiences are just the opposite—they are disconnected from mind and intellect. , dissatisfied with the performance of duty, and feeling deep grief in conscience. The effect of these feelings on him shows that his compassion is born of delusion.

slocks.shlok_name:
आचार्याः पितरः पुत्रास्तथैव च पितामहाः ।
मातुलाः श्वशुराः पौत्राः श्यालाः सम्बन्धिनस्तथा ॥ १-३४॥
slocks.meaning: Guruses, fathers, sons, grandfathers, maternal uncles, grandsons, father-in-law, grandsons, brothers-in-law, and other relatives are present here willing to give up their lives and wealth.
slocks.summary: Dronacharya and Kripacharya were Arjuna's gurus; Bhishma and Somadatta were his paternal grandfathers; people like Bhurishrava (son of Somadatta) were his paternal cousins; Purujita, Kuntibhoja, Shalya, and Shakuni were his maternal uncles; Dhritarashtra's hundred sons were his cousins; Lakshmana (son of Duryodhana) was like his progeny;

slocks.shlok_name:
एतान्न हन्तुमिच्छामि घ्नतोऽपि मधुसूदन ।
अपि त्रैलोक्यराज्यस्य हेतोः किं नु महीकृते ॥ १-३५॥
निहत्य धार्तराष्ट्रान्नः का प्रीतिः स्याज्जनार्दन ।
slocks.meaning: O Govinda, of what avail to us are a kingdom, happiness or even life itself when all those for whom we may desire them are now arrayed on this battlefield? O Madhusūdana, when teachers, fathers, sons, grandfathers, maternal uncles, fathers-in-law, grandsons, brothers-in-law and other relatives are ready to give up their lives and properties and are standing before me, why should I wish to kill them, even though they might otherwise kill me? O maintainer of all living entities, I am not prepared to fight with them even in exchange for the three worlds, let alone this earth. What pleasure will we derive from killing the sons of Dhṛutarāṣhṭra?
slocks.summary: Dhritarashtra's hundred sons were his cousins; Lakshmana (Duryodhana's son) was his offspring; Arjuna was referring to the diversity of his relatives present on the battlefield. First, Why should they want to kill me even though I am their relative and well-wisher? And secondly, Even if they want to kill me, why should I want to kill them?

slocks.shlok_name: पापमेवाश्रयेदस्मान्हत्वैतानाततायिनः ॥ १-३६॥
slocks.meaning: O Sustainer of Life! What joy will we get from killing the sons of Dhritarashtra? Even though they are cruel, even if we kill them, we will incur a definite sin.
slocks.summary:
Using the word 'Yadyapi' twice in the above stanza to justify his desire not to kill his kinsmen, Arjuna repeats, Yedyapi, even if I kill them, what satisfaction will I get from such a victory?

Fighting under extreme conditions And killing is considered an irreligious activity

slocks.shlok_name:
तस्मान्नार्हा वयं हन्तुं धार्तराष्ट्रान्स्वबान्धवान् ।
स्वजनं हि कथं हत्वा सुखिनः स्याम माधव ॥ १-३७॥
slocks.meaning: Sin will overcome us if we slay such aggressors. Therefore it is not proper for us to kill the sons of Dhṛutarāṣhṭra and our friends. What should we gain, O Kṛuṣhṇa, husband of the goddess of fortune, and how could we be happy by killing our own kinsmen?
slocks.summary: Fighting and killing in extreme situations are considered irreligious activities, which later lead to penance and guilt. The Vedas say, non-violence is the great virtue, and violence is a sin, except in a few exceptional cases. Ma hinsyat sarva bhutani Do not kill any living creature. Here, Arjuna does not want to kill his kinsmen, as he considers it a sin. However, the Vasishtha Smriti (verse 3.19) says that there are six types of atatayis. , against whom we have a right to defend ourselves: whoever sets fire to one's house, whoever poisons one's food, whoever wants to kill, whoever wants to rob one's property, whoever comes to abduct one's wife, and whoever usurp one's kingdom. Manu Smriti (8.351) says that if one kills such a tyrant in self-defense, it is not considered a sin.

slocks.shlok_name:
यद्यप्येते न पश्यन्ति लोभोपहतचेतसः ।
कुलक्षयकृतं दोषं मित्रद्रोहे च पातकम् ॥ १-३८॥
slocks.meaning: Their ideology is dominated by greed and they see nothing wrong in destroying their relatives or betraying friends out of revenge.
slocks.summary: Although Arjuna was a warrior by nature, he abhorred unnecessary violence. The incident at the end of the Mahabharata war expresses this aspect of his character. A hundred Kauravas were destroyed, but Ashwatthama, son of Dronacharya, retaliated, in the night camp of the Pandavas. entered and killed all the five sons of Draupadi while they were sleeping. Arjuna seized Ashwatthama, bound him like an animal and brought him to the feet of Draupadi, who was moaning pitifully.

slocks.shlok_name:
कथं न ज्ञेयमस्माभिः पापादस्मान्निवर्तितुम् ।
कुलक्षयकृतं दोषं प्रपश्यद्भिर्जनार्दन ॥ १-३९॥
slocks.meaning: O Janārdana, although these men, their hearts overtaken by greed, see no fault in killing one’s family or quarreling with friends, why should we, who can see the crime in destroying a family, engage in these acts of sin?
slocks.summary: Nevertheless, being soft-hearted and forgiving, she said that Ashwatthama should be forgiven as he was the son of his guru Dronacharya. Bhima, on the other hand, wanted to kill Ashwatthama immediately. Arjuna looked to Sri Krishna to resolve this dilemma. , who said, The venerable best Brahmin, even for a short time, has deviated from the religion deserves forgiveness. But one who has come to kill with deadly weapons must be punished.Arjuna understood Sri Krishna's dubious instruction. He did not kill Ashwatthama, but instead cut the back of the brahmin's head, removed the bead from his forehead, and expelled him from the camp. As such, Arjuna's nature was to avoid violence as much as possible. In this particular situation, he says, he knows that it is improper to kill relatives and the elderly. There should be no quarrel with uncles, guests, dependents, children, old people, physicians and relatives. Arjuna thus concluded that the Kauravas, swayed by greed, deviated from their propriety and lost their prudence, but why should he himself, who had no sinful intention, engage in such a heinous act?

slocks.shlok_name:
कुलक्षये प्रणश्यन्ति कुलधर्माः सनातनाः ।
धर्मे नष्टे कुलं कृत्स्नमधर्मोऽभिभवत्युत ॥ १-४०॥
slocks.meaning: With the destruction of dynasty, the eternal family tradition is vanquished, and thus the rest of the family becomes involved in irreligion.
slocks.summary: Every clan has age-old traditions and ancient practices, which are followed by the elderly members of the family to pass on the best values and ideals to the next generations. These traditions help the family members to follow human values and religious propriety. If these elders before time If they die, their future generations are deprived of family guidance and training. Arjuna points out that when clans are destroyed, their traditions die with them, and the remaining family members become irreligious and adulterous. activities develop, so that they lose the opportunity for spiritual liberation. Thus, according to him, clan elders should never be killed.

slocks.shlok_name:
अधर्माभिभवात्कृष्ण प्रदुष्यन्ति कुलस्त्रियः ।
स्त्रीषु दुष्टासु वार्ष्णेय जायते वर्णसङ्करः ॥ १-४१॥
slocks.meaning: When irreligion is prominent in the family, O Kṛuṣhṇa, the women of the family become polluted, and from the degradation of womanhood, O descendant of Vṛuṣhṇi, comes unwanted progeny.
slocks.summary: Vedic culture gave women a very high place in society and the necessity of virtuous qualities in women was given utmost importance. Hence the Manu Smriti says, yatra naryastu pujayante ramante tatar devata: (3.56) meaning, Where Women lead pure and virtuous lives, and are worshiped by the whole society for their purity, thereby pleasing the heavenly gods.” However, when women become immoral, irresponsible men take advantage of them by engaging in adultery; this results in unwanted progeny.

slocks.shlok_name:
सङ्करो नरकायैव कुलघ्नानां कुलस्य च ।
पतन्ति पितरो ह्येषां लुप्तपिण्डोदकक्रियाः ॥ १-४२॥
slocks.meaning: An increase of unwanted population certainly causes hellish life both for the family and for those who destroy the family tradition. The ancestors of such corrupt families fall down, because the performances for offering them food and water are entirely stopped.

slocks.shlok_name:
दोषैरेतैः कुलघ्नानां वर्णसङ्करकारकैः ।
उत्साद्यन्ते जातिधर्माः कुलधर्माश्च शाश्वताः ॥ १-४३॥
slocks.meaning: By the evil deeds of those who destroy the family tradition and thus give rise to unwanted children, all kinds of community projects and family welfare activities are devastated.

slocks.shlok_name:
उत्सन्नकुलधर्माणां मनुष्याणां जनार्दन ।
नरके नियतं वासो भवतीत्यनुशुश्रुम ॥ १-४४॥
slocks.meaning: O Kṛuṣhṇa, maintainer of the people, I have heard by disciplic succession that those who destroy family traditions dwell always in hell.

slocks.shlok_name:
अहो बत महत्पापं कर्तुं व्यवसिता वयम् ।
यद्राज्यसुखलोभेन हन्तुं स्वजनमुद्यताः ॥ १-४५॥
slocks.meaning: Alas, how strange it is that we are preparing to commit greatly sinful acts. Driven by the desire to enjoy royal happiness, we are intent on killing our own kinsmen.
slocks.summary: Arjuna mentions the many evil consequences of this possible war, but he is unable to see that if such evil people are given the opportunity to flourish in society, the result will actually be an increase in the dominance of evil. To express his astonishment, 'Aho' uses the word. The word 'bat' means, 'terrible consequences'. Arjuna says, How surprising it is that we have decided to engage in sinful activities despite knowing the dire consequences of this war.

slocks.shlok_name:
यदि मामप्रतीकारमशस्त्रं शस्त्रपाणयः ।
धार्तराष्ट्रा रणे हन्युस्तन्मे क्षेमतरं भवेत् ॥ १-४६॥
slocks.meaning: Better for me if the sons of Dhṛutarāṣhṭra, weapons in hand, were to kill me unarmed and unresisting on the battlefield.
slocks.summary: As often happens, people are unable to see their own faults and instead blame the situation and other persons. Similarly, Arjuna feels that Dhritarashtra's sons were motivated by greed but he is not. can see that the flow of his compassion is not a transcendental sensation, but a mundane stupidity based on the ignorance of considering oneself as a body. The difficulty of all Arjuna's arguments is to justify the infatuation arising out of his own bodily attachment, weakness of heart and detachment from duty. was using it. Sri Krishna will explain in the next chapters why Arjuna's arguments are flawed.

slocks.shlok_name:
सञ्जय उवाच ।

एवमुक्त्वार्जुनः सङ्ख्ये रथोपस्थ उपाविशत् ।
विसृज्य सशरं चापं शोकसंविग्नमानसः ॥ १-४७॥
slocks.meaning:
Sañjaya said:
 Arjuna, having thus spoken on the battlefield, cast aside his bow and arrows and sat down on the chariot, his mind overwhelmed with grief.
slocks.summary: Usually when a person is speaking, he gets carried away by emotions, and similarly Arjuna's grief, which began to unfold in verse 1.28, has now reached its climax. He has absorbed his religious duties. The struggle to become is dropped with reckless resignation, which is in stark contrast to the state of self-surrender to the path of knowledge and devotion. It is necessary to make it clear here that Arjuna was not devoid of spiritual knowledge like an initiate. He had lived in the divine world and his father, had also received instruction from Indra, the king of heaven. In fact, he was male in his previous birth and endowed with supernatural knowledge. (Nara-Narayana was a dualism, in which Nara was the absolute soul and Narayana was the Supreme Soul.) This is evidenced by the Mahabharata war. The former derives from the fact that Arjuna left the entire Yadusena for Duryodhana and chose only Lord Krishna for his side. He had a firm belief that he would never be defeated if God was on his side. desirous of uttering for welfare, and therefore seeing an opportune occasion, he created disturbance in Arjuna's mind.

slocks.shlok_name:
ॐ तत्सदिति श्रीमद्भगवद्गीतासूपनिषत्सु
ब्रह्मविद्यायां योगशास्त्रे श्रीकृष्णार्जुनसंवादे
अर्जुनविषादयोगो नाम प्रथमोऽध्यायः ॥ १॥

summary.en:
The second chapter of the Bhagavad Gita is Sankhya Yoga. This is the most important chapter of the Bhagavad Gita as Lord Krishna condenses the teachings of the entire Gita in this chapter. This chapter is the essence of the entire Gita. 
Sankhya Yoga can be categorized into 4 main topics - 
1. Arjuna completely surrenders himself to Lord Krishna and accepts his position as a disciple and Krishna as his Guru. He requests Krishna to guide him on how to dismiss his sorrow.
2. Explanation of the main cause of all grief, which is ignorance of the true nature of Self.
3. Karma Yoga - the discipline of selfless action without being attached to its fruits.
4. Description of a Perfect Man - One whose mind is steady and one-pointed.

The third chapter of the Bhagavad Gita is Karma Yoga or the Path of Selfless Service. Here Lord Krishna emphasizes the importance of karma in life. He reveals that it is important for every human being to engage in some sort of activity in this material world. Further, he describes the kinds of actions that lead to bondage and the kinds that lead to liberation. Those persons who continue to perform their respective duties externally for the pleasure of the Supreme, without attachment to its rewards get liberation at the end.

meaning.en: Path of Knowledge and the Disciplines of Action

summary.en: The fourth chapter of the Bhagavad Gita is Jnana Karma Sanyasa Yoga. In this chapter, Krishna glorifies the Karma Yoga and imparts the Transcendental Knowledge (the knowledge of the soul and the Ultimate Truth) to Arjuna. He reveals the reason behind his appearance in this material world. He reveals that even though he is eternal, he reincarnates time after time to re-establish dharma and peace on this Earth. His births and activities are eternal and are never contaminated by material flaws. Those persons who know and understand this Truth engage in his devotion with full faith and eventually attain Him. They do not have to take birth in this world again.

The fifth chapter of the Bhagavad Gita is Karma Sanyasa Yoga. In this chapter, Krishna compares the paths of renunciation in actions (Karma Sanyas) and actions with detachment (Karma Yoga) and explains that both are means to reach the same goal and we can choose either. A wise person should perform his/her worldly duties without attachment to the fruits of his/her actions and dedicate them to God. This way they remain unaffected by sin and eventually attain liberation.

The sixth chapter of the Bhagavad Gita is Dhyana Yoga. In this chapter, Krishna reveals the Yoga of Meditation and how to practise this Yoga. He discusses the role of action in preparing for Meditation, how performing duties in devotion purifies one's mind and heightens one's spiritual consciousness. He explains in detail the obstacles that one faces when trying to control their mind and the exact methods by which one can conquer their mind. He reveals how one can focus their mind on Paramatma and unite with the God.

The seventh chapter of the Bhagavad Gita is Gyaan Vigyana Yoga . In this chapter, Krishna reveals that he is the Supreme Truth, the principal cause and the sustaining force of everything. He reveals his illusionary energy in this material world called Maya, which is very difficult to overcome but those who surrender their minds unto Him attain Him easily. He also describes the four types of people who surrender to Him in devotion and the four kinds that don't. Krishna confirms that He is the Ultimate Reality and those who realize this Truth reach the pinnacle of spiritual realization and unite with the Lord.

The eighth chapter of the Bhagavad Gita is Akshara Brahma Yoga. In this chapter, Krishna reveals the importance of the last thought before death. If we can remember Krishna at the time of death, we will certainly attain him. Thus, it is very important to be in constant awareness of the Lord at all times, thinking of Him and chanting His names at all times. By perfectly absorbing their mind in Him through constant devotion, one can go beyond this material existence to Lord's Supreme abode.

meaning.en: Yoga through the King of Sciences

summary.en: The ninth chapter of the Bhagavad Gita is Raja Vidya Yoga. In this chapter, Krishna explains that He is Supreme and how this material existence is created, maintained and destroyed by His Yogmaya and all beings come and go under his supervision. He reveals the Role and the Importance of Bhakti (transcendental devotional service) towards our Spiritual Awakening. In such devotion, one must live for the God, offer everything that he possesses to Him and do everything for Him only. One who follows such devotion becomes free from the bonds of this material world and unites with the Lord.

meaning.en: Yoga through Appreciating the Infinite Opulences of God

summary.en: The tenth chapter of the Bhagavad Gita is Vibhooti Yoga. In this chapter, Krishna reveals Himself as the cause of all causes. He describes His various manifestations and opulences in order to increase Arjuna's Bhakti. Arjuna is fully convinced of Lord's paramount position and proclaims him to be the Supreme Personality. He prays to Krishna to describe more of His divine glories which are like nectar to hear.

meaning.en: Yoga through Beholding the Cosmic Form of God

summary.en: The eleventh chapter of the Bhagavad Gita is Vishwaroopa Darshana Yoga. In this chapter, Arjuna requests Krishna to reveal His Universal Cosmic Form that encompasses all the universes, the entire existence. Arjuna is granted divine vision to be able to see the entirety of creation in the body of the Supreme Lord Krishna.

The twelfth chapter of the Bhagavad Gita is Bhakti Yoga. In this chapter, Krishna emphasizes the superiority of Bhakti Yoga (the path of devotion) over all other types of spiritual disciplines and reveals various aspects of devotion. He further explains that the devotees who perform pure devotional service to Him, with their consciousness, merged in Him and all their actions dedicated to Him, are quickly liberated from the cycle of life and death. He also describes the various qualities of the devotees who are very dear to Him.

meaning.en: Yoga through Distinguishing the Field and the Knower of the Field

summary.en: The thirteenth chapter of the Bhagavad Gita is Ksetra Ksetrajna Vibhaaga Yoga. The word kshetra means the field, and the kshetrajna means the knower of the field. We can think of our material body as the field and our immortal soul as the knower of the field. In this chapter, Krishna discriminates between the physical body and the immortal soul. He explains that the physical body is temporary and perishable whereas the soul is permanent and eternal. The physical body can be destroyed but the soul can never be destroyed. The chapter then describes God, who is the Supreme Soul. All the individual souls have originated from the Supreme Soul. One who clearly understands the difference between the body, the Soul and the Supreme Soul attains the realization of Brahman.

slocks.shlok_name:
अर्जुन उवाच ।

दृष्ट्वेमं स्वजनं कृष्ण युयुत्सुं समुपस्थितम् ॥ १-२८॥

slocks.meaning:
Arjuna said:
 My dear Kṛuṣhṇa, seeing my friends and relatives present before me in such a fighting spirit, I feel the limbs of my body quivering and my mouth drying up
slocks.summary: Anurag can be either mundane or spiritual. Enchantment for one's relatives is a worldly affection, arising out of carnal conceptions of life. Believing ourselves to be a body, we become attached to the relatives of the body. This attachment is ignorance. is based on and drags one down to the mayic consciousness. Ultimately such attachment results in suffering, because, with the end of the body, family ties also come to an end. On the other hand, the Supreme Father God is our soul's father, mother, friend, guru, and Beloved. Accordingly, attachment to Him at the level of the soul is a spiritual attitude, which elevates the consciousness and illuminates the intellect. Love for God is like an ocean, in whose vastness all is absorbed, whereas love for carnal relations is narrow and discriminating. . Here, Arjuna was experiencing worldly attachment, which was drowning his mind in an ocean of depression, causing him to tremble at the mere thought of his duty.

न काङ्क्षे विजयं कृष्ण न च राज्यं सुखानि च ।
slocks.meaning: I do not see how any good can come from killing my own kinsmen in this battle, nor can I, my dear Kṛuṣhṇa, desire any subsequent victory, kingdom, or happiness.
slocks.summary: His mind began to become dizzy at the thought. Due to this unsteadiness of mind, he became possessed by inferior spirits and began to accept misleading ominous signs and foresaw disastrous and imminent consequences.

slocks.shlok_name: किं नो राज्येन गोविन्द किं भोगैर्जीवितेन वा ॥ १-३२॥

Arjuna felt that even if he did such a cruel thing to gain the kingdom, the victory would bring him no happiness in the end. would not. slocks.meaning: What is the benefit of the kingdom, the pleasures or the life for which we long, they are all arrayed before us for battle.
slocks.summary: Here, Arjuna is exhibiting a low level of sensitivity, and is confused by idealism. Indifference to worldly possessions and material pleasures is an admirable spiritual virtue, but Arjuna is not feeling spiritual. On the contrary, his Illusion masquerading as words of compassion. Virtuous attitudes bring inner harmony, contentment, and happiness to the soul. If Arjuna's compassion were transcendental, he would have been elevated by such feelings, but his experiences are just the opposite—they are disconnected from mind and intellect. , dissatisfied with the performance of duty, and feeling deep grief in conscience. The effect of these feelings on him shows that his compassion is born of delusion.

slocks.summary: Dronacharya and Kripacharya were Arjuna's gurus; Bhishma and Somadatta were his paternal grandfathers; people like Bhurishrava (son of Somadatta) were his paternal cousins; Purujita, Kuntibhoja, Shalya, and Shakuni were his maternal uncles; Dhritarashtra's hundred sons were his cousins; Lakshmana (son of Duryodhana) was like his progeny;

slocks.meaning: O Govinda, of what avail to us are a kingdom, happiness or even life itself when all those for whom we may desire them are now arrayed on this battlefield? O Madhusūdana, when teachers, fathers, sons, grandfathers, maternal uncles, fathers-in-law, grandsons, brothers-in-law and other relatives are ready to give up their lives and properties and are standing before me, why should I wish to kill them, even though they might otherwise kill me? O maintainer of all living entities, I am not prepared to fight with them even in exchange for the three worlds, let alone this earth. What pleasure will we derive from killing the sons of Dhṛutarāṣhṭra?
slocks.summary: Dhritarashtra's hundred sons were his cousins; Lakshmana (Duryodhana's son) was his offspring; Arjuna was referring to the diversity of his relatives present on the battlefield. First, Why should they want to kill me even though I am their relative and well-wisher? And secondly, Even if they want to kill me, why should I want to kill them?

slocks.shlok_name: पापमेवाश्रयेदस्मान्हत्वैतानाततायिनः ॥ १-३६॥

slocks.summary:
Using the word 'Yadyapi' twice in the above stanza to justify his desire not to kill his kinsmen, Arjuna repeats, Yedyapi, even if I kill them, what satisfaction will I get from such a victory?

Fighting under extreme conditions And killing is considered an irreligious activity

तस्मान्नार्हा वयं हन्तुं धार्तराष्ट्रान्स्वबान्धवान् ।
स्वजनं हि कथं हत्वा सुखिनः स्याम माधव ॥ १-३७॥
slocks.meaning: Sin will overcome us if we slay such aggressors. Therefore it is not proper for us to kill the sons of Dhṛutarāṣhṭra and our friends. What should we gain, O Kṛuṣhṇa, husband of the goddess of fortune, and how could we be happy by killing our own kinsmen?
slocks.summary: Fighting and killing in extreme situations are considered irreligious activities, which later lead to penance and guilt. The Vedas say, non-violence is the great virtue, and violence is a sin, except in a few exceptional cases. Ma hinsyat sarva bhutani Do not kill any living creature. Here, Arjuna does not want to kill his kinsmen, as he considers it a sin. However, the Vasishtha Smriti (verse 3.19) says that there are six types of atatayis. , against whom we have a right to defend ourselves: whoever sets fire to one's house, whoever poisons one's food, whoever wants to kill, whoever wants to rob one's property, whoever comes to abduct one's wife, and whoever usurp one's kingdom. Manu Smriti (8.351) says that if one kills such a tyrant in self-defense, it is not considered a sin.

slocks.shlok_name:

slocks.summary: Although Arjuna was a warrior by nature, he abhorred unnecessary violence. The incident at the end of the Mahabharata war expresses this aspect of his character. Arjuna seized Ashwatthama, bound him like an animal and brought him to the feet of Draupadi, who was moaning pitifully.

slocks.meaning: O Janārdana, although these men, their hearts overtaken by greed, see no fault in killing one’s family or quarreling with friends, why should we, who can see the crime in destroying a family, engage in these acts of sin?
slocks.summary: Nevertheless, being soft-hearted and forgiving, she said that Ashwatthama should be forgiven as he was the son of his guru Dronacharya. Bhima, on the other hand, wanted to kill Ashwatthama immediately. Arjuna looked to Sri Krishna to resolve this dilemma. , who said, The venerable best Brahmin, even for a short time, has deviated from the religion deserves forgiveness. But one who has come to kill with deadly weapons must be punished.Arjuna understood Sri Krishna's dubious instruction. He did not kill Ashwatthama, but instead cut the back of the brahmin's head, removed the bead from his forehead, and expelled him from the camp. As such, Arjuna's nature was to avoid violence as much as possible. In this particular situation, he says, he knows that it is improper to kill relatives and the elderly. There should be no quarrel with uncles, guests, dependents, children, old people, physicians and relatives. Arjuna thus concluded that the Kauravas, swayed by greed, deviated from their propriety and lost their prudence, but why should he himself, who had no sinful intention, engage in such a heinous act?

If these elders before time If they die, their future generations are deprived of family guidance and training. Arjuna points out that when clans are destroyed, their traditions die with them, and the remaining family members become irreligious and adulterous. activities develop, so that they lose the opportunity for spiritual liberation. Thus, according to him, clan elders should never be killed.

slocks.summary: Vedic culture gave women a very high place in society and the necessity of virtuous qualities in women was given utmost importance. Hence the Manu Smriti says, yatra naryastu pujayante ramante tatar devata: (3.56) meaning, Where Women lead pure and virtuous lives, and are worshiped by the whole society for their purity, thereby pleasing the heavenly gods.” However, when women become immoral, irresponsible men take advantage of them by engaging in adultery; this results in unwanted progeny.

He had lived in the divine world and his father, had also received instruction from Indra, the king of heaven. In fact, he was male in his previous birth and endowed with supernatural knowledge. (Nara-Narayana was a dualism, in which Nara was the absolute soul and Narayana was the Supreme Soul.) This is evidenced by the Mahabharata war. meaning.en: Yoga through Understanding the Three Modes of Material Nature

summary.en: The fourteenth chapter of the Bhagavad Gita is Gunatraya Vibhaga Yoga. In this chapter, Krishna reveals the three gunas (modes) of the material nature - goodness, passion and ignorance which everything in the material existence is influenced by. He further explains the essential characteristics of each of these modes, their cause and how they influence a living entity affected by them. He then reveals the various characteristics of the persons who have gone beyond these gunas. The chapter ends with Krishna reminding us of the power of pure devotion to God and how attachment to God can help us transcend these gunas.

meaning.en: The Yoga of the Supreme Divine Personality

summary.en: The fifteenth chapter of the Bhagavad Gita is Purushottama Yoga. In Sanskrit, Purusha means the All-pervading God, and Purushottam means the timeless & transcendental aspect of God.        Krishna reveals that the purpose of this Transcendental knowledge of the God is to detach ourselves from the bondage of the material world and to understand Krishna as the Supreme Divine Personality, who is the eternal controller and sustainer of the world. One who understands this Ultimate Truth surrenders to Him and engages in His devotional service.

meaning.en: Yoga through Discerning the Divine and Demoniac Natures

summary.en: The sixteenth chapter of the Bhagavad Gita is Daivasura Sampad Vibhaga Yoga. In this chapter, Krishna describes explicitly the two kinds of natures among human beings - divine and demoniac. Those who possess demonaic qualities associate themselves with the modes of passion and ignorance do not follow the regulations of the scriptures and embrace materialistic views. These people attain lower births and further material bondage. But people who possess divine qualities, follow the instructions of the scriptures, associate themselves with the mode of goodness and purify the mind through spiritual practices. This leads to the enhancement of divine qualities and they eventually attain spiritual realization.

meaning.en: Yoga through Discerning the Three Divisions of Faith

summary.en: The seventeenth chapter of the Bhagavad Gita is Sraddhatraya Vibhaga Yoga. In this chapter, Krishna describes the three types of faith corresponding to the three modes of the material nature. Lord Krishna further reveals that it is the nature of faith that determines the quality of life and the character of living entities. Those who have faith in passion and ignorance perform actions that yield temporary, material results while those who have faith in goodness perform actions in accordance with scriptural instructions and hence their hearts get further purified.

meaning.en: Yoga through the Perfection of Renunciation and Surrender

summary.en: The eighteenth chapter of the Bhagavad Gita is Moksha Sanyas Yoga. Arjuna requests the Lord to explain the difference between the two types of renunciations - sanyaas(renunciation of actions) and tyaag(renunciation of desires). Krishna explains that a sanyaasi is one who abandons family and society in order to practise spiritual discipline whereas a tyaagi is one who performs their duties without attachment to the rewards of their actions and dedicating them to the God. Krishna recommends the second kind of renunciation - tyaag. Krishna then gives a detailed analysis of the effects of the three modes of material nature. He declares that the highest path of spirituality is pure, unconditional loving service unto the Supreme Divine Personality, Krishna. If we always remember Him, keep chanting His name and dedicate all our actions unto Him, take refuge in Him and make Him our Supreme goal, then by His grace, we will surely overcome all obstacles and difficulties and be freed from this cycle of birth and death.
